name: Bogomolov conjecture
summary: The Bogomolov conjecture is a statement in number theory about the distribution of "small height" points on algebraic varieties, such as curves or abelian varieties. It essentially states that if a subvariety is not a "special" (or torsion) subvariety, then it cannot contain a Zariski-dense set of points with small height. The conjecture has two main versions: one for curves and one for higher-dimensional varieties, and both have been proven in many cases.
head: Let \(X\) be an irreducible subvariety of an abelian variety \(A\) over a number field (or function field), and assume that \(X\) contains a Zariski-dense set of points with canonical height zero (or, more generally, "small height").Â
